Award.AwardTitle: GOALI: Fundamental Studies and Modeling of Pulsed Tube Hydroforming

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objectives of this Grant Opportunity for Academic Liaison with Industry (GOALI) research project are to a) create a fundamental understanding of the enhanced formability of metals during pulsed tube hydroforming, and b) develop analytical and numerical models of the process that will allow industries such as automotive and aerospace to capitalize on this behavior. Traditionally, loading during tube hydroforming is applied monotonically. Recently, it was demonstrated on actual components that if the loading is applied in a pulsed fashion (frequency ~1 Hz), significant gains in formability can be reaped. The mechanism(s) that lead to such improvements are presently unknown. The first objective of this research is to clarify these mechanisms by investigating different hypotheses experimentally. The materials to be examined are Advanced High Strength Steels and Aluminum alloys. The experimental findings will guide the research team into developing the analytical and numerical tools required by the industrial end-users to implement such technologies.

This advanced hydroforming process and the models developed in this research will benefit society at large by reducing the environmental impact, and by enabling more aggressive product designs of products such as automobiles. Graduate and undergraduate students, including underrepresented groups in engineering, will benefit from the industrial focus of this project and from the integration of the results into the curriculum. The NSF Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) and Research Experience for Teachers (RET) frameworks will be used to attract talented participants to aid with the research tasks. The RET participants will also identify high-school students to be engaged in research over the summer, thus attracting more students to STEM disciplines. Finally, the results of this research will be effectively communicated to industry through workshops conducted with the industrial partners (Alcoa, Ford, U.S. Steel).

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project investigated the fundamental science behind the pulsed loading of materials, and created knowledge and methods that can be used by the industry for science-based decisions of pulsed tube hydroforming. In this process, instead of a continuously increasing application of the loads, these are applied in a slowly-varying manner. It was shown experimentally that this enhances the ability of materials (steel alloys typical of automotive applications) to deform. Hence, more complex shapes can be created and thus, more imaginative and environmentally friendly products such as automobiles can be offered to the consumer.

The physical mechanisms behind this enhancement were unknown before this research. Through a combination of experiments and analysis, it was discovered that for some materials, such as stainless steel, this enhancement is due to the heating up of the materials as they deform (Cullen and Korkolis, 2013). The pulsed application of the load leads to more benign heating, in comparison to conventional loading. This research led also to the creation of a simple and effective method for isothermal testing of materials. The research on pulsed loading was expanded from uniaxial to biaxial, using a specially designed cruciform specimen (Deng et al., 2015), which has been suggested to us to include in the next edition of the ISO standard for cruciform testing. It also involved the creation of a tabletop testing machine for cruciform specimens (Wilson et al, 2013). The work on biaxial loading-unloading can directly benefit the sheet metal forming community on issues of springback, especially relevant to automotive lightweighting materials such as Advanced High Strength Steel and Aluminum alloys.

The second part of the project involved the understanding of the formability and hydroforming of tubes. The ring hoop tension test was studied in detail (Dick and Korkolis, 2014) and used to study the response of extruded aluminum tubes (Dick and Korkolis, 2015a). Furthermore, a new method for testing of thin-walled tubes under tension and shear, called the ring plane strain test, was invented (Dick and Korkolis, 2015b). The research also involved the creation of a tabletop tube hydroforming machine, as well as sophisticated finite element models of the process. This modeling demonstrated the need of accurate material modeling to be input in the finite element simulations, which verified and justified the fundamental science research performed in this project.

The project lead to an extensive training of human capital: 6 graduate and 9 undergraduates (5 REU participants), 1 high-school teacher and 1 student (who went on to study engineering) as well as 2 visiting students from France and S. Korea. An example of training and professional development is the creation of the cruciform specimen testing machine. When the students presented this work to the ME Industrial Advisory Board, they were met with unhindered enthusiasm. Numerous members (engineers from BS to PhD) were open and explicit about the value that they saw in this experience, and stated clearly to the students that this experience made them extremely marketable, way beyond what they would expect from a new graduate.  The project has also lead to international collaborations in Japan and S. Korea, including a research visit by the PI and a graduate student for 6 weeks in Tokyo. The project has involved 2 major US companies (Ford Motor Company, U.S. Steel). The PI gave lectures at companies and universities around the world (US, Germany, Netherlands, Japan, China).
